details.title: Laplace-transforms and fast-repair approximations for multiple availability and its generalizations

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. Stat., Univ. of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa

p: Maxim S. Finkelstein received the M.Sc. (1971) degree from St. Petersburg State University (Russia), and the Ph.D. (1979) and D.Sc. (1992) degrees in operations research from St. Petersburg Elektropribor Institute.

He is a Professor with the Department of Mathematical Statistics, University of the Orange Free State, South Africa. He has published more than 90 papers on various aspects of reliability and applied stochastic processes modeling in journals of the former Soviet Union and in journals such as J. Applied Probability, J. Statistical Planning and Inference, the IEEE TRANSACTIONSON RELIABILITY, Reliability Engineering and System Safety, Probability in Engineering and Informational Sciences. He has authored four books published in Russian.

p: Vladimir I. Zarudnij received the M.Sc. (1959) degree from the St. Petersburg Polytechnic Institute, and the Ph.D. (1965) degree in operations research from St. Petersburg Elektropribor Institute.
He had published more than 50 papers on structural reliability and related topics. He has authored two books published in Russian.

details.abstract: Stochastic models, describing multiple availability, are analyzed for a system with periods of operation and repair that form an alternating renewal process with exponential times to failure and repair. For the simplest case multiple availability is defined as the probability that the system is available in the interval [0, t) at each moment of demand. Instants of demand form a homogeneous Poisson process. This setting is generalized to considering a possibility of one or more points of unavailability in [0, t) as well as time redundancy. The corresponding integral equations are derived and solved (wherever possible) via the Laplace transform. A fast repair approach is also applied to each case under consideration and simple approximate relations for multiple availability are obtained. The fast repair approximation makes it possible to derive approximate solutions for problems that cannot be solved by the first approach. The accuracies of the fast repair approximations are analyzed. Generalizations to arbitrary failure and repair distributions are also discussed.

links.abstract: A stochastic model of mission effectiveness for a system which is required to perform a random number of tasks during its mission is developed. Mission effectiveness is defined as a combined measure of availability and reliability at each task-arrival time. An analytic model is derived under a general set of assumptions. Other models are outlined to show the wide applicability of this model for mission effectiveness.
